arts.ttl: First impressions of 'low-key' Tuchel & his England team
arts.sum: After an uneventful win over Albania, what are chief football writer Phil McNulty's first impressions of Thomas Tuchel's England?

arts.ttl: Lewis-Skelly gamble pays off for Tuchel as he balances impatience and reality | Jonathan Liew
arts.sum: Young Arsenal left-back was the brightest light on an intriguing opening night for England’s new head coach It was the 68th minute when Jarrod Bowen and Anthony Gordon trotted down the steps, stripped and ready to come on. As they waited on the touchline, Thomas Tuchel leaned conspiratorially close, imparting crucial last-minute tactical instructions. You, go left. You, attack this half-space. You, spin him around the diagonal. You, watch for the trapezium pass. Or whatever. I don’t really understand a lot of the jargon they use these days. Meanwhile Bowen and Gordon listened intently, waiting for the break in play. And waited. And kept waiting. The clock ticked over to 69, 70, 71 minutes. Tuchel was still delivering little tactical messages. You, show him the roses. You, click-clack, flip-flap, bing-bong. You, always on the shoulder blade, always perceiving. On the field, England were still patiently passing the ball around, not out of any particular urgency or desire but just because it seemed to feel quite nice. Continue reading...

arts.ttl: Liverpool transfer news: Reds receive financial boost in Marc Guehi pursuit?
arts.sum: Liverpool receive a financial boost in their quest to sign England international Marc Guehi from Crystal Palace this summer.

arts.ttl: Thomas Tuchel’s construction of England’s high-speed monorail begins | Barney Ronay
arts.sum: The new head coach brought an intensity and interesting selection to Wembley and was pleasingly harsh in victory The first thing with any new England manager is the visuals. Here it is, a new way of standing, a new energy, a new outline. How are we going to feel? What is Thomas Tuchel? Do I like this thing? What are the semiotics of body shape, stride pattern, arm movements, that will come to signify triumph or despair? At Wembley for day one of his fast-cut mini-era, Tuchel looked good. There is a distinct kind of charisma in that skinny frame, angular, tall, oddly impressive, like a strolling duke. Leaders wear hats. The Tuchel cap is good. Maybe city centre fashion retailers will be doing a blue Tommy T by next summer. Maybe its all going to be fine. Maybe it’s going to be smart Gareth, Gareth+, Gareth without the really Gareth bits. Maybe it’s just Albania. Continue reading...

arts.ttl: The Verdict: Lewis-Skelly shines on debut but England with room for improvement?

arts.ttl: Thomas Tuchel explains what he did NOT like about England's win over Albania - and reveals the two players he wanted MORE from
arts.sum: Thomas Tuchel kicked off his England reign with a 2-0 victory over Albania on Friday night but the German manager was not left overly impressed by his team's performance at Wembley.
